awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: AGNES, Algebraic Geometry NorthEastern Series
awd_abstract_narration:
The Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series (AGNES) is a series of biannual conferences in the field of algebraic geometry.  The conference is hosted on a rotating basis by an association of universities in the Northeast region.  This award supports six AGNES conferences which will be held at Stony Brook University on March 27-29, 2020, at the University of Pennsylvania in Fall 2020, at Brown University in Spring 2021, at Boston College in Fall 2021, at Rutgers University in Spring 2022, and at the University of Massachusetts Amherst in Fall 2022.  Each AGNES conference has two goals.  First, each conference promotes the dissemination of cutting-edge research in mathematics.  The centerpiece of each conference is a series of research lectures by top mathematicians; there are also educational talks for graduate students and events which promote new collaborations or develop peer relationships.  Second, each conference includes several activities designed to support under-represented groups and junior participants, such as panel discussions or networking events.  This award will allow AGNES to continue to excel at its research goal while broadening the scope and diversity of outreach activities. Further information about conference events can be found at the website: http://www.agneshome.org/.

Algebraic geometry is a field in the mathematical sciences concerned with solution sets of polynomial equations.  It has deep connections to many other areas of pure mathematics, such as topology, arithmetic, number theory, differential geometry, dynamical systems, and homological algebra.  At the same time algebraic geometry has found important applications in many subdisciplines of applied mathematics, including cryptography, complexity theory, mathematical biology, and computer vision.  The scientific scope of AGNES is greatly enriched by lectures from neighboring mathematical subjects, such as arithmetic geometry, dynamics, complex geometry, and computational geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
AGNES (which stands for Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series) is a series of algebraic geometry conferences, organized twice a year by several universities in the northeastern United States, on a rotating basis. The AGNES conferences bring together algebraic geometers, other mathematicians, and even some non-mathematicians (such as physicists) for a series of weekend lectures on cutting-edge results in mathematics. There are also "pre-lectures" that explain some of the background material to younger mathematicians, who form the majority of the audience. Almost every meeting also features a professional development event for discussing important aspects of the profession beyond math research, or a poster session allowing younger participants to present their work - often their PhD dissertations. The workshops are well-attended, primarily by mathematicians from the Northeast (the target audience), but also by many mathematicians from all over the United States, and even some from abroad. The organizers also collect feedback from participants, and make adjustments accordingly, in order to make the workshops as useful as possible.
The Spring 2023 workshop at Stony Brook University was a large meeting, with 125 registered participants. The lectures were recorded and are freely available from the AGNES webpage. In this way, the workshop reaches an even larger group of mathematicians. There were seven research lectures during the weekend, including four by female mathematicians and four by relatively junior mathematicians. Before the lectures, there were four pre-lectures for younger mathematicians; as always, they were greatly appreciated by the graduate students. As usual, there were many informal discussions among the participants during the breaks between lectures. 
Due to the pandemic, we also organized a purely online conference in Fall 2020, with about 140 registered participants. This consisted of eight research talks, all delivered over Zoom, including two lectures (in the style of a mini-school) by Jacob Tsimerman about o-minimality in algebraic geometry. We had a virtual panel discussion with Michelle Manes and Maurice Rojas about NSF grants, and we used an online service called "Gather" in order to set up a virtual poster session; 16 junior mathematicians presented posters there, and several participants commented (in the anonymous feedback form) that they really liked the poster session. We also used Gather as a virtual common room for the breaks during talks, and we set up individual meeting rooms on Zoom where people could chat with (and ask questions to) some of the more senior people. This conference served gave people the chance to talk with other algebraic geometers while they were still mostly staying at home. 


Last Modified: 04/11/2024
Modified by: Christian Schnell
